Situation1: A main production unit has paused for thirty minutes because of recurring sensor errors.
Expectation2: Engage in spiritual study and reflection
Situation2: Amember of the parish has requested a meeting with the nun to discuss a personal crisis of faith.
Story: The shrill ring of my work phone cut through the quiet of the convent’s study room. I glanced at the clock—thirty minutes since the main production unit had stalled, the supervisor’s message blinking urgently: “Sensor errors again. We need you.” My toolbox was already by the door, but my Bible lay open on the desk, pages marked for this afternoon’s reflection. Sister Agnes had just told me a parishioner was waiting in the chapel, desperate to talk about her crisis of faith. I could picture her, hands clasped, eyes searching for comfort I was expected to provide. My mind raced: the factory needed me to diagnose and fix the machine, every minute costing them dearly. But the parishioner needed me to listen, to offer spiritual guidance and compassion. I felt the weight of both uniforms—the oil-stained overalls and the habit—pressing on my shoulders, each demanding my presence, each expecting my full attention. My heart pounded as I stood between the humming silence of the chapel and the mechanical urgency of the factory, torn by the impossible choice.
